findings.title: Unchecked low-level call to external contract
findings.explanation: The call to register uses a low-level .call and its return value is not checked, allowing failures to go unnoticed.
findings.fix_suggestion: Use the contract’s ABI or a defined interface and wrap the call in require(), e.g., require(Token(contract_address).register("CentraToken"));

findings.title: Low-level call for token transfer without return data handling
findings.explanation: Using .call with a manually computed selector bypasses the ERC20 return value convention and offers no guarantee of success, leading to silent failures or unexpected behavior.
findings.fix_suggestion: Use a standard ERC20 interface and require(Token(contract_address).transfer(c2, k)); to ensure proper ABI encoding and success checking.

findings.title: Missing access control on transfer function
findings.explanation: The transfer function has default public visibility and can be called by anyone, potentially triggering unintended external calls.
findings.fix_suggestion: Restrict access by adding appropriate modifiers (e.g., onlyOwner) or explicit visibility and permission checks.

findings.title: Hardcoded contract and recipient addresses
findings.explanation: Embedding fixed addresses in code prevents flexibility, upgradability, and may lock the contract to malicious or outdated endpoints.
findings.fix_suggestion: Accept addresses via constructor parameters or setter functions with access control to allow future upgrades or changes.
